results.title: Join the navy and see the world they say
results.creator_credit: Ron Baguley, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Inspired by his childhood hero, ‘Uncle Jack’, Ron Baguley enlisted in the Navy at the ripe age of 16. “Join the Navy and see the world they say!” In 1952, Ron was plucked from his job as a carpenter and thrown into a life at sea, serving initially in the Korean Conflict. Ron tracks his incredibly journey from a young recruit to a senior warrant officer.
results.title_for_label: Join the navy and see the world they say
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ron Baguley, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

Ron tracks his incredibly journey from a young recruit to a senior warrant officer.

results.title: John Miles: drafted Vietnam
results.brief_description: John Miles recalls the 29th of September 1965 as the date that he commenced his National Service. While he was away, the political climate changed dramatically in Australia. Miles remembers his experience of the Vietnam War and his struggles once home in Australia. Miles’ treatment on return to Australia initially made left him feeling bitter, but a trip back to Vietnam was crucial to his personal transformation and healing.
results.description: John Miles recalls the 29th of September 1965 as the date that he commenced his National Service. While he was away, the political climate changed dramatically in Australia. results.title: An interview with Patrick Bourke
results.brief_description: Patrick Bourke was 16 when he grew onions with his father. Wanting to get out of this, he decided to join the navy. After convincing his father, he started work on his first ship H.M.A.S Adele, sighting subs and signalling wherever he was. Patrick retells some of his tales out at sea.

results.title: An interview with Cyril Sayles
results.brief_description: At the age of 16, Cyril Sayles, not wanting to continue his manual labour in the mines, decided to join the army. Having lied about his age, he had a special made uniform and was off to fight the Germans in World War II. Cyril humorously shares his story of strength and courage, through his battle and imprisonment during the war.
results.description: At the age of 16, Cyril Sayles, not wanting to continue his manual labour in the mines, decided to join the army. Having lied about his age, he had a special made uniform and was off to fight the Germans in World War II. Cyril humorously shares his story of strength and courage, through his battle and imprisonment during the war.

Cyril humorously shares his story of strength and courage, through his battle and imprisonment during the war.

results.title: Interview with Ben Whitham
results.brief_description: In war, you are discouraged from keeping records or taking photographs. However, soldiers broke those rules in order to help remember. Born on a small soldier’s settlement farm, Ben Witham grew up hearing stories about the war. Having a father who served in Gallipoli, to his own service in World War II, Witham recalls the camaraderie and the lighter side of war. He emphasises the bonds of fellow servicemen and the celebration of this during commemorations for ANZACs.

results.title: Every man for himself
results.creator_credit: Arthur Bedford, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Hiding from the Germans amongst olive trees in Greece, Arthur Bedford and his fellow soldiers were told to get out. “Every man for himself”. Not only did they manage to escape, they managed to fend off a enemy bombing attack and didn’t suffer a single casualty.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arthur Bedford, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: A Boy called "Rabbit"
results.creator_credit: Ken Cumming, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ken Cumming’s dearest memory of the time he served in Vietnam was a young boy by the name of “Rabbit”. While “Rabbit” couldn’t speak English, he was popular with the Australian soldiers for his fast running and bravery.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Cumming, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Big blip, small blip
results.creator_credit: Knox McKenzie, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Trained as a radar operator, Knox McKenzie saw himself posted around Australia throughout World War II, and eventually on Melville Island. It was an isolating job, waiting for signal “blips” to pick up planes coming in. A big blip was a friend and a small blip was a foe. McKenzie’s innate independence helped him to see the entire experience as an education and one to remember for the rest of his life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Knox McKenzie, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [St Arnaud Veterans]
results.brief_description: While many didn’t see active service, these ten veterans from St Arnaud count their time in the army as the most important part of their lives. Proud of their service, they tell of exciting adventures, adjusting to big changes and the friends they made along the way.
results.title_for_label: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [St Arnaud Veterans]
results.description: While many didn’t see active service, these ten veterans from St Arnaud count their time in the army as the most important part of their lives. Proud of their service, they tell of exciting adventures, adjusting to big changes and the friends they made along the way.
description_for_label: While many didn’t see active service, these ten veterans from St Arnaud count their time in the army as the most important part of their lives. Proud of their service, they tell of exciting adventures, adjusting to big changes and the friends they made along the way.
